title-group.article-title: Fried-Potato Diet Causes Vitamin A Deficiency in an Autistic Child

abstract.p: A 5-year-old boy with autism developed dry eye and xerophthalmia. Serum vitamin A was undetectable. Dietary history revealed a markedly altered intake consisting of only fried potatoes and rice balls for 2 years. Fried potatoes contain no vitamin A. Autism is a multifaceted developmental disorder infrequently accompanied by abnormal eating practices. To the authors’ knowledge, most children with autism who develop dietary vitamin A deficiency have consumed an excess of fried potatoes. Attention to possible vitamin A deficiency is essential when fried potatoes are consumed exclusively.

body.p: Eating disorders are common in autism, which is characterized by poor social interactions, communication problems, and stereotypic behaviors. The spectrum of eating problems includes pica, refusal of particular foods, food intake abnormalities, overeating, and a variety of anorectic behaviors. They may be quite troubling in the management of the child and can give rise to serious complications.1 Herein, we report on an autistic child with vitamin A deficiency and secondary xerophthalmia. To our knowledge, most children with autism who developed dietary vitamin A deficiency ate excess, or even exclusively, fried potatoes. Clinicians should keep in mind that a fried-potato diet for autistic children may cause progressive vision loss.

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: The patient was a 5-year-old boy, born by spontaneous vertex delivery at 40 gestational weeks. He had gained head control at 4 months, walked alone at 14 months, and used 1-word sentences at 36 months. He showed communication problems and stereotypic behaviors. He was diagnosed with autism at 3 years of age.

He presented with a poor diet and dry eyes. His diet consisted of only fried potatoes, rice balls, and water for 2 years. He had previously eaten bread and fruits but refused them after a viral infection.

On physical examination, his mean (SD) weight was 17.8 (0.63) kg and mean (SD) height was 110.9 (0.28) cm. His body mass index was 14.5 kg/m2. He had marked bilateral conjunctival swelling with a dry and granular appearance. The conjunctivae were keratinized, and there was bilateral corneal ulceration and scarring (see Figure 1). He had no evidence of glossitis or cheilosis. His abdomen was soft and flat without hepatosplenomegaly. He had dry skin with desquamation.

caption.p: Left: the cornea had an ulcer and a scar. Right: the conjunctiva was dry, granular, and keratinized.

sec.p: Routine laboratory tests revealed slight anemia (hemoglobin, 11.3 g/dL; mean corpuscular volume, 90.6 fL). Serum iron was low at 43 µg/dL and ferritin was 154.2 ng/mL. The pre–serum albumin and retinol binding protein levels were low at 4.7 mg/dL and 0.3 mg/dL, respectively. Serum vitamin A was undetectable (<15 µg/L; normal range, 200–600 µg/L). Serum vitamin B12 was normal and folate was low at 3.0 ng/mL (normal range, 5–21 ng/mL) (see Table 1). Malnutrition was considered to be the cause of vitamin A deficiency with secondary xerophthalmia in this case. Nutrition supplementation with a multivitamin including vitamin A was given orally followed by 1500 µg/kg body weight of vitamin A for 5 days. The serum vitamin A level rose to 215 µg/L. His conjunctiva showed moistening and his skin improved.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: We described an autistic child whose diet was so chronically rigid and restrictive that he developed vitamin A deficiency with xerophthalmia. Laboratory tests revealed low levels of calcium, phosphorus, pre–serum albumin and retinol binding protein levels, 25-hydroxy-vitamin D, and folate. Low levels of vitamin D and folate were the result of inadequate intake for a long time. He had a slight normocytic anemia combined with a microcytic and macrocytic anemia due to iron and folate deficiency. Low iron and high ferritin concentrations might have occurred because he came to the hospital soon after acute gastroenteritis.

The behavior of autistic children is infrequently associated with a propensity for eating a narrow variety of foods.2 Anecdotally, autistic children eat only “yellow” foods (ie, French fries, chicken nuggets, etc). Fugazzi et al3 reported their favorite foods to be fried potatoes, candy, chicken nuggets, bananas, and green beans. Although fried potatoes contain abundant carbohydrate and fat and are highly caloric, they do not contain vitamin A.

In the literature to date, there have been 4 prior case reports of autistic children who developed dietary vitamin A deficiency (see Table 2).4-7 Three of the 4 children had a preference for fried potatoes. Clark et al4 reported symptomatic vitamin A and D deficiencies in an 8-year-old with autism whose diet consisted of only fried potatoes and water over 2 years. Uyanik et al6 reported food intake abnormalities causing vision loss in an autistic child who ate only fried potatoes and drank only water for 4 years. McAbee et al7 reported permanent visual loss due to dietary vitamin A deficiency in an autistic adolescent whose diet was limited to potato chips, pretzels, cookies, and other snack foods.

sec.p: Although a so-called picky eater who prefers fried potatoes will not be thin, vitamin A deficiency is likely to emerge due to the prolonged nature of this eating disorder. Careful nutrition monitoring of autistic children should include vitamin A intake to detect potentially reversible deficiencies. Serum testing of vitamin A levels should also be considered, especially in the presence of conjunctival irritation, behavioral changes, or symptoms of impending visual impairment. Aid from a registered dietitian knowledgeable in these issues can be invaluable to the nutrition health of children with autism.
